 This idea arose from Einstein trying to challenge quantum mechanics. He and two other scientists - Podolsky and Rosen (IIRC) - did not accept that nature was ultimately probabilistic as QM indicates, but rather deterministic. So they devised a theoretical proof, which came to be known as the EPR thought experiment (EPR being the first letters of their last names). The debate was when a property was determined: whether something could actually be in a probabilistic superposition states or not. 
 
 In an dumbed down version of the EPR experiment ...
 
 Some properties in nature are conserved. For example, a positive charge cannot be created unless an equal amount of negative charge is created. And this is exactly what happens during pair production: an electron and a positron are formed at the same time (they then usually quickly mutually annihilate, creating a burst of gamma radiation). Another quantity that is conserved is spin. What is spin? That's actually complicated, but in simple terms you can think about it as being like the Earth spinning on its axis. Just as Venus and Earth spin in opposite directions on their axes, so too can particles. And, if two particles with spin are created, then their spins must be opposite in order to cancel out so that total spin to be conserved.
 
 EPR considered a pair of spin-possessing particles created by pair creation, but made to fly apart in opposite directions, later to have their spin detected as either spin up or spin down. According to EPR, the spin of the two particles was determined from the instant of their creation. According to quantum mechanics, the two particles' spins were indeterminate: the particles were in a superposition state of BOTH up AND down, until a measurement was made. EPR said that QM position was ridiculous and proved it with their experiment, because, if the particles were sent in opposite directions at the speed of light and then one of the particle's spin was detected, then INSTANTANEOUSLY the other particle's spin would be determined. In other words, a measurement way over there would INSTANTANEOUSLY cause an effect way over somewhere else: at a speed greater than the speed of light. Since no information or effect can travel faster than the speed of light, it was IMPOSSIBLE - according to EPR - for the quantum mechanics' view to be correct. The particles' spins must be determined at the moment of their creation, not at the moment of one of them being measured. In fact, Einstein was so against the QM view here that he mockingly called it "spooky action at a distance".
 
 EPR's thought experiment was fine as far as a thought experiment went, but the QM gang did not accept it, since QM had been so successful. What was needed was a way to test it. Later, someone named Bell came up with a set of inequalities that could prove which was case if the experiment could actually be performed. In other words, the deterministic and the probabilistic (QM) views predict different results, and applying statistics to them could settle the matter: if only the experiment could actually be performed.
 
 Well, later (beginning in the 1980s?), the technology to perform the experiments finally was available. When the experiments were performed, Bell's inequalities applied to the results showed that the quantum mechanics view was the correct one. As counterintuitive as it may be, for entangled particles, a measurement of particle X can have an INSTANTENOUS effect on particle Y, no matter how far apart the two particles are.

 "Collpase of the wave function" deals with the ending of superposition.
 
 Superposition is when a particle is in more than one state simultaneously (such as being BOTH spin up AND spin down). A wave function is a mathematical description of a system in superposition, and has multiple solutions, each representing one of the possible states of the system. The probability of finding a particle in any one of those solutions' state is proportional to the square of the absolute value of that particular solution. So one can say what the state will PROBABLY be when the wave function collapses to only one solution, but one cannot say what it WILL be. The wave function is collapsed from many values (superposition) to just one (determined) by a measurement or observation of the system. 
 
 Not all QM interpretations involve the collapse of a wave function: some avoid it. For example, the MWI (Many World Interpretation) holds that the superposition does not ACTUALLY collapse into only one determined state, but that rather every possible state is actualized. How? By the creation of another universe! So if a particle is in a superposition state of both spin up and spin down, and a measurement is made to fix its state, then the universe bifurcates and in one universe the particle of found to be spin up and in the other universe it is found to be spin down.
 
 
 
 
 PS: I am not a physicst. I don't claim to have 100% knowledge of quantum mechanics, it's just something I've read about on my own.

The curent (read: publishable) story regarding Hallucigenia is:
 
 
Hallucigenia is an extinct genus of animal found as fossils in the Middle Cambrian-aged Burgess Shale formation of British Columbia, Canada. It was named by Simon Conway Morris when he re-examined Charles Walcott's Burgess Shale genus Canadia in 1979. Morris found that what Walcott had called one genus in fact included several quite different animals. One of them was so unusual that nothing about it made much sense. Since the species clearly was not a polychaete worm, Morris had to provide a new generic name to replace Canadia. Morris named the species Hallucigenia sparsa because of its "bizarre and dream-like quality" (like a hallucination).

 
 Though if you ask any biologist who was around in the late '70s Morris spent weeks unsuccessfully trying to produce his reconstruction untill one night when he was under the effects of Hallucinogenic substances. 
 The fact that he reproduced it upsidedown and that noone has yet figured out which end was its mouth and which was its arse merely adds to the 'psychodelic' qualities of the animal.
